content.title: Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)
content.definition: A non-invasive vascular laboratory test comparing systolic blood pressure at the ankle to that in the arm, used for diagnosis and severity assessment of peripheral arterial disease.

physiologic_basis.normal: Ankle pressure slightly higher than arm due to pulse wave amplification
physiologic_basis.pad: Arterial stenosis causes pressure drop distal to lesion
physiologic_basis.incompressibility: Calcified vessels may have falsely elevated pressures

screening: Adults age 50-64 with risk factors (diabetes, smoking, dyslipidemia, hypertension)
Adults <50 with diabetes plus one additional risk factor
Known atherosclerotic disease in other beds

equipment: Blood pressure cuffs (appropriate size for arm and ankle)

patient_preparation.avoid: Exercise, smoking, caffeine for 2 hours prior

measurement_steps: Measure brachial pressure in both arms using Doppler
Use higher brachial pressure as denominator
Measure ankle pressure at dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial
Use higher ankle pressure for each leg as numerator
Calculate ABI = higher ankle pressure / higher brachial pressure

doppler_technique.inflate_cuff: Above systolic pressure until signal disappears
doppler_technique.deflate_slowly: Note pressure when Doppler signal returns

severe_pad.interpretation: Severe PAD, critical limb ischemia likely

incompressible.interpretation: Non-compressible calcified vessels, need toe pressures

diabetic_patients.issue: Medial arterial calcification causes falsely elevated ABI
diabetic_patients.solution: Use toe-brachial index (TBI) - digital arteries rarely calcify

exercise_abi.indication: Normal resting ABI with exertional symptoms
exercise_abi.protocol: Walk on treadmill until symptoms, then immediate ABI

segmental_pressures.gradient: >20-30 mmHg between adjacent segments suggests stenosis

wound_healing.abi_05: Unlikely to heal with conservative measures
wound_healing.absolute_pressure: Ankle pressure <50 mmHg predicts poor healing

clinical_pearls: ABI <0.9 = PAD; ABI >1.4 = incompressible vessels, use TBI
Exercise ABI helpful when resting ABI normal but symptoms present
Diabetics often have calcified vessels - always check TBI
ABI is also a cardiovascular risk marker (lower = higher mortality)
Ankle pressure <50 mmHg predicts poor wound healing
learning_objectives: Interpret ABI values for PAD severity
board_review_points: ABI is independent CV risk predictor
